intro: Oxydectes gnidiacea, commonly known as the desert sandmat, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a low-growing, mat-forming perennial with hairy stems and small, clustered flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant has adapted to harsh desert conditions through its deep root system and ability to store water in its fleshy leaves. Its flowers are typically pollinated by insects, and it produces small, dry fruits that contain seeds. Oxydectes gnidiacea plays a role in stabilizing sandy soils and providing habitat for small desert organisms.
